docs.title: 3. Manage Risks
docs.text:
• Monitor identified implementation risks
  • Identify new risks from changes
  • Update risk register
  • Execute mitigation strategies

docs.title: 4. Provide Analysis for Architecture Change Management
docs.text:
• Assess impact of proposed changes
  • Evaluate alignment with business strategy
  • Consider technology trends
  • Analyze cost and benefit of changes

docs.title: 5. Develop Change Requirements
docs.text:
• Capture change requests from stakeholders
  • Document business justification
  • Define scope of changes
  • Prioritize based on value and impact

docs.title: 6. Manage Governance Process
docs.text:
• Convene Architecture Board regularly
  • Review and approve changes
  • Monitor compliance
  • Make governance decisions

docs.title: 7. Activate the Process to Implement Change
docs.text:
• Determine which ADM phase(s) to invoke
  • Initiate new architecture cycle if needed
  • Update architecture incrementally if appropriate
  • Manage architecture version control

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Output Description Architecture Updates Revised architecture documents and artifacts Change Requests Approved changes triggering new ADM cycles Statement of Architecture Work (updated) For new architecture initiatives Architecture Contract (new) For new implementation projects Compliance Assessments Ongoing compliance monitoring results

docs.title: Change Drivers
docs.text: Phase H responds to three types of changes:

docs.title: 1. Business Changes
docs.text: Change Type Example Impact Strategy shift New market entry May require new capabilities Organizational change Merger or acquisition Integration architecture needed Process change New business model Business architecture revision Regulatory change New compliance requirement Data and security updates

docs.title: 2. Technology Changes
docs.text: Change Type Example Impact New technologies Cloud-native platforms Technology architecture opportunities End of life Vendor discontinuing product Technology replacement needed Security threats New vulnerabilities Security architecture updates Performance issues Scalability problems Infrastructure changes

docs.title: 3. Architecture Improvements
docs.text: Change Type Example Impact Lessons learned Better patterns discovered Standards and reference models update Technical debt Accumulated shortcuts Remediation projects Optimization Cost reduction opportunities Rationalization initiatives Innovation New architecture approaches Capability enhancement

docs.title: Change Request Process
docs.text:
1. Request Submitted
  2. Stakeholder identifies need for change
  3. Change request form completed

  4. Business justification provided

  5. Initial Assessment

  6. Architecture team reviews request
  7. Quick feasibility check

  8. Categorize by type and urgency

  9. Impact Analysis

  10. Assess effect on current architecture
  11. Identify affected domains and stakeholders
  12. Estimate effort and cost

  13. Evaluate benefits and risks

  14. Prioritization

  15. Compare with other change requests
  16. Consider business value and urgency
  17. Assess resource availability

  18. Place in change backlog

  19. Architecture Board Review

  20. Present high-priority changes
  21. Discuss implications and alternatives
  22. Make go/no-go decision

  23. Allocate resources if approved

  24. Implementation

  25. Determine approach (new ADM cycle vs. incremental update)
  26. Execute change
  27. Update architecture repository
  28. Communicate to stakeholders

docs.title: Change Request Categories
docs.text: Category Handling Simplification Architecture improvement opportunity Incremental Small refinement Re-architecting Significant change Emergency Critical urgent fix

docs.title: What to Monitor
docs.text: Area Monitoring Focus Frequency Implementation progress Project delivery vs. roadmap Monthly Benefits realization Actual vs. expected value Quarterly Technology landscape Emerging technologies, vendor changes Ongoing Business environment Strategy, organization, market changes Quarterly Architecture compliance Conformance to standards Per project Technical debt Accumulation of shortcuts and compromises Quarterly Risks and issues Threats to architecture objectives Monthly

docs.title: Monitoring Mechanisms
docs.text: Mechanism Purpose Dashboards Real-time view of architecture health Compliance audits Periodic assessment of adherence Stakeholder surveys Satisfaction and concerns Technology watch Horizon scanning for trends Metrics and KPIs Quantitative performance measures Post-implementation reviews Lessons from completed projects

docs.title: Architecture Versioning
docs.text:
Manage architecture as a versioned asset:

Version Type When to Use Example Major Significant re-architecting 1.0 → 2.0 (cloud migration) Minor Incremental enhancements 1.1 → 1.2 (new integration pattern) Patch Small corrections 1.1.0 → 1.1.1 (standard clarification)

docs.title: Architecture States
docs.text: State Description Duration Current Actively implemented and maintained Until superseded Transition Being phased in or out Migration period Baseline Reference point for changes Historical record Target Planned future state Until implemented Sunset Being decommissioned Retirement period Retired No longer in use Archived

docs.title: Triggering New ADM Cycles
docs.text: Phase H determines when to launch a new ADM cycle:

docs.title: Triggers for New Cycle
docs.text: Trigger Description Example Scheduled refresh Regular architecture review Annual or bi-annual cycle Significant change Major business or technology shift Digital transformation, merger Accumulated changes Many small changes need reconciliation Quarterly incremental updates New initiative Major project or program New product line, market entry Architecture maturity Capability advancement Move from segment to enterprise architecture

docs.title: Cycle Scope Options
docs.text: Option Description When to Use Full ADM cycle All phases from Preliminary through H Major transformation, new architecture Partial cycle Selected phases (e.g., B, C, D, E, F) Update specific domains Phase iteration Repeat single phase Refine one area (e.g., re-do Phase B) Incremental update Direct architecture edits Minor corrections, small enhancements

docs.title: Architecture Governance Board
docs.text: The Architecture Board operates continuously in Phase H:

docs.title: Board Responsibilities
docs.text: Responsibility Description Review change requests Assess and approve architecture changes Monitor compliance Oversee adherence to architecture Resolve exceptions Decide on dispensation requests Set priorities Determine architecture work priorities Allocate resources Assign architecture capacity Escalate issues Raise unresolved matters to executive level

docs.title: Board Meeting Cadence
docs.text: Meeting Type Frequency Purpose Regular meetings Monthly or bi-monthly Routine governance decisions Project reviews Per governance checkpoint Compliance assessments Strategic sessions Quarterly Architecture direction and planning Emergency meetings As needed Critical issues requiring immediate decision

docs.title: Continuous Improvement
docs.text: Phase H drives architecture practice maturity:

docs.title: Improvement Areas
docs.text: Area Activities Standards and patterns Update based on lessons learned Processes Streamline ADM application Tools Enhance architecture tools and repository Skills Train architects, develop competencies Stakeholder engagement Improve communication and collaboration Metrics Refine measurement of architecture value

docs.title: Architecture Maturity Assessment
docs.text:
Periodically assess EA capability maturity:

Maturity Level Characteristics Level 0: None No formal EA practice Level 1: Initial Ad-hoc architecture, project-based Level 2: Developing Some standards, emerging governance Level 3: Defined Documented processes, consistent application Level 4: Managed Measured performance, proactive governance Level 5: Optimizing Continuous improvement, strategic asset

docs.title: Relationship to Other Phases
docs.text:
Phase Relationship Phase G Provides lessons learned and change requests to Phase H Preliminary Phase H may trigger update to architecture framework Phase A Phase H launches new architecture cycles starting at Phase A All phases Phase H determines which phases to invoke for changes Requirements Mgmt Continuous requirement management operates alongside Phase H

Phase H is continuous — it never really ends, transitioning to new ADM cycles as needed.

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Phase H provides ongoing governance and change management for architecture
  • Monitors three types of changes: Business, Technology, Architecture improvements
  • Change requests processed, prioritized, and routed appropriately
  • Phase H determines when to launch new ADM cycles
  • Architecture Board operates continuously to govern architecture
  • Architecture managed as versioned, living asset
  • Monitoring includes: implementation progress, benefits realization, technology trends
  • Change categories: Simplification, Incremental, Re-architecting, Emergency
  • Phase H feeds back to Preliminary (framework updates) or Phase A (new cycles)
  • Continuous improvement of architecture capability and maturity
  • Architecture states: Current, Transition, Baseline, Target, Sunset, Retired
  • Phase H ensures architecture stays aligned with business over time

docs.title: Preliminary Phase
docs.text: The Preliminary Phase prepares the organization for successful EA projects by defining "where, what, why, who, and how" architecture will be practiced in the enterprise.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The Preliminary Phase is about preparation and initiation — establishing or enhancing the Enterprise Architecture (EA) capability within an organization before embarking on architecture development.

This phase ensures that the architecture effort: - Aligns with business directives - Has appropriate organizational support - Uses an appropriate, tailored framework - Follows defined principles and governance

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text: Objective Description Define the enterprise Determine scope of organizations impacted Identify stakeholders Confirm governance and support frameworks Establish EA team Define and establish the EA team and organization Define principles Identify and establish Architecture Principles Tailor TOGAF Customize TOGAF framework for organizational needs Implement tools Develop strategy for EA tools and techniques

docs.title: Key Questions Answered
docs.text: The Preliminary Phase answers: - Where do we do architecture? (scope) - What kind of architecture do we need? (domains, deliverables) - Why are we doing architecture? (drivers, goals) - Who is involved? (stakeholders, governance) - How do we do architecture? (framework, principles, processes)

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text: Input Source Board strategies and plans Business strategy documents Business principles, goals, drivers Corporate planning Governance and legal frameworks Compliance requirements Architecture frameworks TOGAF, industry frameworks Existing EA capability Current EA practices (if any) Partnership agreements Collaborations with other organizations

docs.title: 1. Scope the Enterprise Organizations Impacted
docs.text:
• Define the breadth of the enterprise to be addressed
  • Identify all organizations, business units, and partners affected
  • Determine geographic scope

docs.title: 2. Confirm Governance and Support Frameworks
docs.text:
• Review existing governance structures
  • Identify sponsorship and stakeholder support
  • Align with corporate governance processes
  • Establish reporting lines

docs.title: 3. Define and Establish EA Team and Organization
docs.text:
• Determine EA team structure and roles
  • Define responsibilities and authorities
  • Establish architecture board (or equivalent)
  • Identify required skills and competencies

docs.title: 4. Identify and Establish Architecture Principles
docs.text:
• Define business principles
  • Define architecture principles
  • Ensure principles align with business goals
  • Document rationale and implications for each principle

docs.title: 5. Tailor TOGAF Framework
docs.text:
• Customize ADM to organizational needs
  • Adapt terminology to organizational language
  • Select relevant deliverables and artifacts
  • Integrate with existing frameworks and methods

docs.title: 6. Implement Architecture Tools
docs.text:
• Select EA tools and repositories
  • Define modeling standards and notations
  • Establish architecture repository structure
  • Plan for tool deployment and training

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Output Description Organizational Model for EA Structure, roles, responsibilities for EA function Tailored Architecture Framework Customized TOGAF with adapted processes and deliverables Initial Architecture Repository Starting structure for storing architecture assets Architecture Principles Documented principles with rationale and implications Request for Architecture Work Optional trigger for Phase A (if applicable) Architecture Governance Framework Processes and structures for oversight and compliance

docs.title: Architecture Principles
docs.text: Principles are general rules and guidelines intended to be enduring and guide architecture work.

docs.title: Structure of a Principle
docs.text:
Each principle should have:

Element Description Example Name Clear, memorable title Data is an Asset Statement Concise description of the rule Data is a valuable corporate asset that has value beyond immediate transaction Rationale Why this principle exists Accurate and timely data is critical for decision-making Implications Consequences and requirements Requires data governance, stewardship, and quality management

docs.title: Example Principles
docs.text: Principle Statement Maximize Benefit to the Enterprise Decisions are made to maximize enterprise benefit rather than local optimization Business Continuity Operations are designed to ensure continuity despite system failures Compliance with Law Enterprise processes comply with all relevant laws and regulations Data is an Asset Data is managed as a valuable enterprise asset Reuse Before Buy, Buy Before Build Existing solutions are reused; COTS is preferred over custom development Technology Independence Applications are independent of specific technology choices

docs.title: Tailoring the ADM
docs.text: Organizations should adapt TOGAF to their context by:

docs.title: 1. Terminology Adaptation
docs.text:
• Use organizational language (e.g., "solution" vs "application")
  • Align role names with existing job titles
  • Match document names to corporate standards

docs.title: 2. Process Integration
docs.text:
• Integrate ADM with existing processes (SDLC, project management)
  • Align with Agile, DevOps, or other methodologies
  • Connect to portfolio management processes

docs.title: 3. Content Customization
docs.text:
• Select relevant deliverables for organizational needs
  • Adapt templates to corporate standards
  • Define organization-specific viewpoints

docs.title: 4. Governance Alignment
docs.text:
• Connect to existing governance boards
  • Align decision-making processes
  • Integrate compliance requirements

docs.title: Architecture Capability
docs.text:
The Preliminary Phase establishes the Architecture Capability — the organizational ability to practice EA effectively.

Components include:

Component Description Skills and roles EA practitioners, domain architects, business analysts Processes ADM, governance, change management Tools Modeling tools, repositories, collaboration platforms Governance Architecture board, review processes, compliance Standards Modeling notations, documentation templates Communications Stakeholder engagement, reporting mechanisms

docs.title: Relationship to Other Phases
docs.text:
Phase Relationship Phase A Preliminary establishes the framework that Phase A operates within All ADM phases Provides governance, principles, and framework used throughout Requirements Mgmt Establishes the process for managing requirements continuously

The Preliminary Phase is typically executed once to establish the EA capability, then revisited periodically (e.g., annually) to refresh the framework.

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Preliminary Phase is about preparation, not developing architecture
  • Key outputs: Architecture Principles, Tailored Framework, EA Organization
  • Architecture Principles have four parts: Name, Statement, Rationale, Implications
  • Preliminary answers "where, what, why, who, and how" of doing EA
  • This phase establishes the Architecture Capability
  • TOGAF should be tailored to organizational needs — one size does not fit all
  • Preliminary is typically done once at the start, then refreshed periodically

docs.title: Requirements Management
docs.text: Requirements Management is a continuous, dynamic process that operates throughout all ADM phases to identify, store, and manage architecture requirements.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
Requirements Management ensures that: - Architecture requirements are identified and documented - Requirements are tracked and prioritized - Changes to requirements are managed - Requirements flow into and out of ADM phases - Traceability is maintained from requirements to solutions

This phase sits at the center of the ADM, feeding all other phases.

docs.title: 1. Continuous Process
docs.text:
• NOT a one-time phase — operates throughout entire ADM cycle
  • Active during every other ADM phase
  • Continues even during Phase H (ongoing operations)

docs.title: 2. Central to ADM
docs.text:
• Represented by the circle at the center of ADM diagram
  • Feeds requirements TO every phase
  • Receives requirements FROM every phase
  • Ensures alignment across all phases

docs.title: 3. Dynamic and Iterative
docs.text:
• Requirements evolve as architecture develops
  • New requirements emerge during architecture work
  • Requirements are refined and elaborated over time
  • Changes are tracked and managed

docs.title: 4. Process, Not Disposal
docs.text:
• Requirements Management is the process for managing requirements
  • Does NOT prioritize or address requirements — that happens in ADM phases
  • Provides storage, tracking, and change management

docs.title: Objectives
docs.text: Objective Description Identify requirements Capture architecture requirements from stakeholders Store requirements Maintain requirements in a repository Track requirements Monitor status and changes Prioritize requirements Work with phases to determine importance (not RM itself) Manage changes Handle requirement additions, modifications, deletions Ensure traceability Link requirements to architecture and solutions Feed ADM phases Provide relevant requirements to each phase

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text: Input Source Business requirements Stakeholders, business strategy Architecture requirements ADM phases (A, B, C, D, E, F) Change requests Phases G, H, stakeholders Requirements from previous cycles Architecture Repository

docs.title: 1. Identify and Document Requirements
docs.text:
• Gather requirements from stakeholders
  • Capture requirements from each ADM phase
  • Document in standardized format
  • Categorize by type and source

docs.title: 2. Baseline Requirements
docs.text:
• Establish initial set of requirements
  • Create baseline for change tracking
  • Version requirements baseline
  • Communicate to stakeholders

docs.title: 3. Monitor Baseline Requirements
docs.text:
• Track changes to requirements
  • Identify new requirements
  • Monitor requirement status (proposed, approved, implemented)
  • Update requirements repository

docs.title: 4. Assess Change Impacts
docs.text:
• Analyze impact of requirement changes
  • Identify affected architecture domains
  • Determine which ADM phases need revisiting
  • Assess cost and benefit of changes

docs.title: 5. Prioritize Requirements
docs.text:
• Support ADM phases in prioritizing (not RM itself)
  • Consider business value, urgency, dependencies
  • Balance stakeholder needs
  • Align with architecture objectives

docs.title: 6. Manage Approved Changes
docs.text:
• Update requirements repository
  • Communicate changes to affected stakeholders
  • Trigger appropriate ADM phase iterations
  • Maintain requirements traceability

docs.title: 7. Update Requirements Repository
docs.text:
• Store all requirement artifacts
  • Maintain version history
  • Ensure accessibility to architecture team
  • Link requirements to architecture elements

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Output Description Requirements Repository Centralized store of all architecture requirements Requirements Impact Assessment Analysis of how changes affect architecture Updated requirements Revised requirements reflecting changes Requirements Traceability Matrix Links between requirements and architecture elements

docs.title: 1. Business Requirements
docs.text: Type Description Example Functional What the business needs to do "Support online ordering" Process How business operates "Order-to-cash in 24 hours" Capability What business must be able to do "Serve customers in 15 countries"

docs.title: 2. Architecture Requirements
docs.text: Type Description Example Principle Guiding rules "Data is an asset" Standard Technology or approach mandates "Use REST APIs for integration" Pattern Architectural solution templates "Microservices architecture"

docs.title: 3. Technical Requirements
docs.text: Type Description Example Non-functional Quality attributes "99.9% uptime" Constraints Limitations "Must run on existing infrastructure" Interface Integration specifications "Integrate with SAP via OData"

docs.title: 4. Stakeholder Requirements
docs.text: Type Description Example Concerns Stakeholder interests "Minimize disruption during migration" Preferences Stakeholder desires "Prefer cloud-based solutions" Constraints Stakeholder limitations "Budget cannot exceed $2M"

docs.title: Requirements Lifecycle
docs.text:
Requirements progress through states:

Proposed → Analyzed → Validated → Approved → Implemented → Verified
State Description Proposed Requirement identified but not yet analyzed Analyzed Impact and feasibility assessed Validated Confirmed with stakeholders Approved Accepted for implementation Implemented Built into architecture/solution Verified Confirmed as met Rejected Determined not to pursue Deferred Postponed to future cycle

docs.title: Requirements Repository
docs.text: The Requirements Repository stores all architecture requirements.

docs.title: Repository Contents
docs.text: Content Description Requirements catalog List of all requirements Requirements details Full specification for each requirement Relationships Dependencies between requirements Traceability Links to architecture and solutions Change history Versions and changes over time Approval status Current state and approvals Priority and ranking Importance and sequence

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text:
Requirements Repository
├── Business Requirements
│   ├── Functional
│   ├── Process
│   └── Capability
├── Architecture Requirements
│   ├── Principles
│   ├── Standards
│   └── Patterns
├── Technical Requirements
│   ├── Non-Functional
│   ├── Constraints
│   └── Interfaces
└── Stakeholder Requirements
    ├── Concerns
    ├── Preferences
    └── Constraints

docs.title: Requirements Traceability
docs.text: Traceability ensures requirements are linked to architecture elements and solutions.

docs.title: Traceability Matrix Example
docs.text:
Requirement ID Requirement Addressed By Architecture Element Solution Component Status REQ-001 Online ordering Business Process Order Management Process E-commerce Platform Implemented REQ-002 99.9% uptime Infrastructure High Availability Architecture Load Balancer + Redundancy Implemented REQ-003 Customer 360 view Data Architecture Customer MDM MDM Platform In Progress

Traceability answers: - Which requirements are addressed by which architecture elements? - Which solutions implement which requirements? - Are all requirements covered? - Which requirements are not yet implemented?

docs.title: Change Management
docs.text: Requirements Management handles changes to requirements:

docs.title: Change Types
docs.text: Change Type Description Handling New requirement Stakeholder identifies new need Assess impact; determine which ADM phase to engage Modified requirement Existing requirement changes Evaluate impact on current architecture; re-engage affected phases Deleted requirement Requirement no longer valid Remove or mark as obsolete; assess if architecture simplification possible Prioritization change Importance shifts Update roadmap and implementation sequence

docs.title: Change Process
docs.text:
1. Change Requested — Stakeholder or phase identifies need
  2. Impact Assessed — Evaluate effect on architecture
  3. Reviewed — Architecture team or board evaluates
  4. Decision Made — Approve, defer, or reject
  5. Implemented — If approved, update requirements and trigger ADM phases
  6. Communicated — Inform stakeholders

docs.title: Requirements Management and ADM Phases
docs.text:
How Requirements Management interacts with each phase:

Phase RM Interaction Preliminary Establish requirements management process Phase A Capture initial stakeholder requirements and concerns Phase B Receive business requirements; feed business architecture requirements to C Phase C Receive data/app requirements; feed technical requirements to D Phase D Receive technology requirements; feed constraints back to C Phase E Consolidate all requirements; validate completeness Phase F Ensure requirements are addressed in implementation plan Phase G Verify requirements are met in implementations Phase H Manage requirement changes triggering new cycles

Key Point: Requirements flow bidirectionally — phases provide requirements TO RM, and RM provides requirements TO phases.

docs.title: Requirements Management Tools
docs.text:
Common tools and techniques:

Tool/Technique Purpose Requirements repository Central storage (e.g., Jira, Azure DevOps, Confluence) Traceability matrix Link requirements to architecture and solutions Business scenarios Discover and elaborate requirements through scenarios Stakeholder analysis Identify and prioritize stakeholder requirements MoSCoW prioritization Must-have, Should-have, Could-have, Won't-have Impact assessment Evaluate effects of requirement changes

docs.title: Requirements in Architecture Repository
docs.text:
Requirements are stored in the Architecture Repository as part of:

Repository Component Requirements Content Governance Log Requirement decisions and approvals Architecture Landscape Requirements driving architectures Standards Information Base Standard and principle requirements Reference Library Requirement patterns and templates

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: Pitfall Consequence Prevention Requirements not updated Architecture misalignment Regular reviews and updates No traceability Unclear if requirements are met Maintain traceability matrix Requirements not prioritized Everything is "high priority" Formal prioritization process Changes not assessed Architecture impact unknown Mandatory impact analysis Poor stakeholder engagement Missing or incorrect requirements Continuous stakeholder involvement No change control Scope creep Formal change management process

docs.title: Relationship to Other Phases
docs.text:
Requirements Management is unique — it doesn't follow other phases; it operates alongside all phases.

        Requirements Management (Continuous)
                     ↕
    Preliminary → A → B → C → D → E → F → G → H
        ↕         ↕   ↕   ↕   ↕   ↕   ↕   ↕   ↕
    Requirements flow to and from every phase

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Requirements Management is continuous, not a one-time phase
  • Sits at the center of ADM, feeding all other phases
  • It's a process for managing requirements, not for prioritizing them
  • Requirements flow bidirectionally — TO and FROM each ADM phase
  • Handles requirement identification, storage, tracking, change management
  • Does NOT prioritize or address requirements — that's done in ADM phases
  • Three types of requirements: Business, Architecture, Technical (+ Stakeholder)
  • Requirements Repository stores all requirements with traceability
  • Requirements have a lifecycle: Proposed → Analyzed → Validated → Approved → Implemented
  • Change management for requirements triggers appropriate ADM phase iterations
  • Traceability links requirements to architecture elements and solutions
  • Requirements Management establishes the Requirements Repository in Architecture Repository

docs.title: Building Blocks
docs.text: Building Blocks are reusable components of business, IT, or architectural capability that can be combined to deliver architectures and solutions.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Building Blocks enable: - Reusability — Leverage existing components - Modularity — Decompose complex systems into manageable units - Clarity — Clear definition of architectural components - Communication — Common language for architects and implementers - Traceability — Link architecture to implementation

docs.title: What is a Building Block?
docs.text: A Building Block represents a potentially reusable component of enterprise capability.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text:
Characteristic Description Package of functionality Delivers specific capability Well-defined interfaces Clear boundaries and interactions Interoperable Works with other building blocks Potentially reusable Can be leveraged across multiple contexts Replaceable Can be swapped with alternative implementations Published specification Documented capabilities and interfaces

Building Blocks exist at multiple levels of abstraction — from high-level business capabilities to specific technology products.

docs.title: 1. Architecture Building Blocks (ABBs)
docs.text:
Architecture Building Blocks define WHAT functionality is required.

Aspect Description Definition Specification of required capability Focus Functional requirements and interfaces Abstraction Technology-independent where possible Source Architecture Continuum Purpose Define architecture requirements Examples "Customer Management Service", "Order Processing Function", "Data Integration Service"

ABB Characteristics: - Functional specification (what it does) - Interfaces (how it interacts) - Interoperability requirements (what it connects to) - Not tied to specific products or implementation

docs.title: 2. Solution Building Blocks (SBBs)
docs.text:
Solution Building Blocks define HOW functionality is implemented.

Aspect Description Definition Implementation of ABB requirements Focus Specific products, technologies, configurations Abstraction Concrete, implementation-specific Source Solutions Continuum Purpose Implement architecture Examples "Salesforce CRM", "SAP ERP Order Module", "MuleSoft ESB"

SBB Characteristics: - Product or code specification (vendor, version) - Implementation details (configuration, customization) - Performance characteristics (non-functional specifics) - Deployment details (where and how it runs)

docs.title: Relationship Between ABBs and SBBs
docs.text:
Architecture Building Block (ABB)
         ↓
    "What" is needed
         ↓
   (maps to one or more)
         ↓
Solution Building Block (SBB)
         ↓
     "How" it's implemented

docs.title: Example Mapping
docs.text:
ABB Description Possible SBBs Customer Relationship Mgmt Capability to manage customer interactions Salesforce CRM, Microsoft Dynamics 365, Custom CRM Application Authentication Service Capability to verify user identity Active Directory, Okta, Auth0, Custom IAM Data Integration Capability to move data between systems MuleSoft, Dell Boomi, Apache Camel, Custom ETL

One ABB may be realized by multiple SBBs (alternatives or combinations).

One SBB may realize multiple ABBs (a product fulfilling several capabilities).

docs.title: Building Block Specification
docs.text: Each Building Block should be documented with:

docs.title: ABB Specification
docs.text: Element Description Name Clear identifier Description What it does and why Functionality Specific capabilities provided Interfaces How it interacts (inputs, outputs, protocols) Dependencies Other building blocks it requires Attributes Key characteristics (performance, security, etc.) Constraints Limitations or requirements

docs.title: SBB Specification
docs.text: Element Description Name Product or component name Version Specific version or release Vendor Provider of the solution Implementation details Configuration, customization Performance characteristics Actual non-functional performance Deployment model On-premise, cloud, SaaS, etc. Interfaces Technical integration points (APIs, protocols) Dependencies Other SBBs or infrastructure required Cost Licensing, operational costs

docs.title: Business Building Blocks
docs.text: Type ABB Example SBB Example Business Service Customer Onboarding Service Onboarding Portal + CRM Integration Business Process Order Fulfillment Process Fulfillment Workflow in ERP System Business Function Inventory Management SAP Inventory Module

docs.title: Data Building Blocks
docs.text: Type ABB Example SBB Example Data Entity Customer Master Data Customer Table in PostgreSQL Data Service Customer Data Access Service Customer API (REST) Data Component Product Catalog Product Database + Cache Layer

docs.title: Application Building Blocks
docs.text: Type ABB Example SBB Example Application Service Payment Processing Service Stripe Payment Gateway Application Component Shopping Cart E-commerce Platform Cart Module Application Function Search Capability Elasticsearch Service

docs.title: Technology Building Blocks
docs.text: Type ABB Example SBB Example Platform Service Application Runtime Kubernetes Cluster Infrastructure Service Compute Service AWS EC2 Instances Network Service Load Balancing AWS Application Load Balancer

docs.title: From ABB to SBB
docs.text:
1. Define ABB (during Phases B, C, D)
  2. Specify required functionality
  3. Define interfaces and dependencies

  4. Document constraints and attributes

  5. Identify Candidate SBBs (during Phase E)

  6. Reuse existing SBBs from portfolio
  7. Purchase COTS products

  8. Build custom SBBs

  9. Select SBB (during Phases E, F)

  10. Evaluate alternatives (make vs. buy vs. reuse)
  11. Assess fit with ABB requirements

  12. Consider cost, risk, alignment

  13. Implement SBB (during Phase G)

  14. Configure or develop SBB
  15. Integrate with other SBBs
  16. Validate against ABB specification

docs.title: Benefits of Reuse
docs.text: Benefit Description Reduced cost Avoid redevelopment of existing capability Faster delivery Leverage proven components Lower risk Use battle-tested solutions Consistency Standardize across enterprise Interoperability Components designed to work together Ease of maintenance Centralized updates benefit all users

docs.title: Reuse Strategy
docs.text:
Reuse before Buy, Buy before Build — a common architecture principle.

Approach When to Use Example Reuse Existing SBB meets requirements Reuse enterprise authentication service Buy (COTS) No existing solution, commercial option available Purchase CRM SaaS Build Unique requirements, strategic differentiator Develop proprietary pricing algorithm

docs.title: Building Block Patterns
docs.text:
Common architectural patterns as building blocks:

Pattern Description Use Case Layered Organize into presentation, business, data layers Traditional enterprise applications Microservices Fine-grained, independent services Cloud-native, scalable applications API Gateway Centralized entry point for APIs API management, security, routing Event-Driven Components communicate via events Real-time processing, decoupled systems Service Mesh Infrastructure layer for service communication Microservices observability, security

docs.title: Building Blocks and Enterprise Continuum
docs.text:
Building Blocks relate to the Enterprise Continuum:

Continuum Level Building Blocks Foundation Generic ABBs applicable across industries Common Systems ABBs for common IT functions (identity, integration) Industry Industry-specific ABBs (banking, healthcare) Organization-Specific ABBs tailored to enterprise needs

SBBs follow a similar continuum in the Solutions Continuum.

See Enterprise Continuum & Repository for details.

docs.title: Building Blocks and ADM Phases
docs.text:
Phase Building Block Activity Phase A Identify high-level building block requirements Phase B Define business building blocks (ABBs) Phase C Define data and application building blocks (ABBs) Phase D Define technology building blocks (ABBs) Phase E Identify candidate solution building blocks (SBBs); make vs. buy decisions Phase F Plan implementation of selected SBBs Phase G Implement, integrate, and validate SBBs Phase H Monitor and optimize building blocks

Building block definition progresses iteratively — starting high-level in Phase A and becoming detailed through Phases B, C, D.

docs.title: Building Block Catalog
docs.text:
Maintain a Building Block Catalog in the Architecture Repository:

Catalog Purpose ABB Catalog List of architecture building blocks SBB Catalog Inventory of available solution building blocks Mapping Matrix Relationships between ABBs and SBBs

Catalog benefits: - Discoverability — Architects find reusable components - Standardization — Promote approved building blocks - Portfolio management — Track investment in building blocks - Rationalization — Identify redundant or underutilized components

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: Pitfall Consequence Prevention Too coarse-grained Building blocks too large to reuse Decompose into finer-grained components Too fine-grained Excessive complexity, overhead Consolidate into cohesive units Unclear interfaces Difficult to integrate Define clear, published interfaces Tight coupling Dependencies hinder reuse Minimize dependencies, use loose coupling Lack of documentation Cannot understand or reuse Document specifications thoroughly No reuse culture Everyone builds from scratch Promote reuse through governance and incentives

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Building Blocks are reusable components of enterprise capability
  • Two types: ABB (Architecture) and SBB (Solution)
  • ABB = "What" is needed (functional specification)
  • SBB = "How" it's implemented (specific product/code)
  • One ABB can map to multiple SBBs (alternative implementations)
  • One SBB can realize multiple ABBs (one product, many functions)
  • ABBs relate to Architecture Continuum; SBBs relate to Solutions Continuum
  • Reuse before Buy, Buy before Build — common principle
  • Building blocks have well-defined interfaces and are interoperable
  • Building block definition progresses through ADM phases (A → B, C, D → E → G)
  • ABBs defined in Phases B, C, D; SBBs selected in Phase E; implemented in Phase G
  • Building blocks span all domains: Business, Data, Application, Technology

docs.title: Enterprise Continuum & Architecture Repository
docs.text: The Enterprise Continuum provides a classification scheme for architectural assets, while the Architecture Repository is the physical store where these assets reside.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The Enterprise Continuum is a virtual repository showing how architectures evolve from generic (applicable to any organization) to specific (tailored to individual enterprise).

It helps architects: - Classify architectural assets - Understand relationships between assets at different abstraction levels - Leverage existing assets rather than starting from scratch - Position organization-specific work in context of industry standards

docs.title: Enterprise Continuum Structure
docs.text: The Enterprise Continuum comprises two complementary continua:

docs.title: 1. Architecture Continuum
docs.text: Classification of architectural assets from generic to specific.

docs.title: 2. Solutions Continuum
docs.text:
Classification of implementation assets from generic to specific.

Both continua work together to provide a complete classification from abstract architecture to concrete implementation.

docs.title: Architecture Continuum
docs.text:
The Architecture Continuum shows the evolution of architecture definitions:

Foundation → Common Systems → Industry → Organization-Specific
(Generic)                                         (Specific)

docs.title: 1. Foundation Architectures
docs.text:
Most generic — applicable across any industry or organization.

Characteristics Examples Maximum reusability TOGAF Technical Reference Model (TRM) Technology-independent ISO/OSI Reference Model Broadly applicable Generic business capability models Minimal customization needed General architectural principles

Purpose: Provide baseline architectural components applicable everywhere.

docs.title: 2. Common Systems Architectures
docs.text:
Somewhat generic — common to many organizations but more specific than Foundation.

Characteristics Examples Common IT functions Identity and Access Management architecture Widely applicable Integration architecture patterns Technology-agnostic but more specific Document management architecture Industry-neutral Enterprise Service Bus patterns

Purpose: Guide the selection and integration of services from Foundation Architectures.

docs.title: 3. Industry Architectures
docs.text:
Industry-specific — tailored to particular industries.

Characteristics Examples Industry-focused Banking reference architecture (BIAN) Domain-specific Healthcare architecture (HL7, FHIR) Regulatory compliance Telecommunications reference architecture (TMForum) Best practices for industry Retail industry models

Purpose: Provide proven patterns for specific industries.

docs.title: 4. Organization-Specific Architectures
docs.text:
Most specific — custom architectures for individual enterprises.

Characteristics Examples Tailored to enterprise Acme Corp Enterprise Architecture Specific business context XYZ Bank Target Architecture Proprietary elements Custom business capabilities Competitive differentiators Unique processes and systems

Purpose: Address specific needs of the organization.

docs.title: Solutions Continuum
docs.text:
The Solutions Continuum mirrors the Architecture Continuum but focuses on implementations:

Foundation → Common Systems → Industry → Organization-Specific
(Generic Products)                        (Custom Solutions)

docs.title: 1. Foundation Solutions
docs.text:
Generic products — usable across industries.

Examples Operating systems (Linux, Windows) Databases (PostgreSQL, Oracle) Programming languages (Java, Python) Cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP)

docs.title: 2. Common Systems Solutions
docs.text:
Reusable components for common IT functions.

Examples Identity management products (Okta, Active Directory) Integration platforms (MuleSoft, Dell Boomi) Content management systems (SharePoint, Alfresco) Monitoring tools (Datadog, Splunk)

docs.title: 3. Industry Solutions
docs.text:
Industry-specific products and packages.

Examples Banking core systems (Temenos, FIS) Healthcare EMR systems (Epic, Cerner) Retail POS systems (Oracle Retail, SAP Retail) Manufacturing ERP (SAP, Oracle Manufacturing)

docs.title: 4. Organization-Specific Solutions
docs.text:
Custom implementations tailored to enterprise.

Examples Proprietary applications Customized COTS implementations Bespoke integrations Organization-specific configurations

docs.title: Relationship Between Continua
docs.text:
Architecture Continuum          Solutions Continuum
        (ABBs)                        (SBBs)

Foundation Architecture ←→ Foundation Solutions
        ↓                            ↓
Common Systems Arch     ←→ Common Systems Solutions
        ↓                            ↓
Industry Architecture   ←→ Industry Solutions
        ↓                            ↓
Org-Specific Arch       ←→ Org-Specific Solutions

Architecture Building Blocks (ABBs) reside in the Architecture Continuum. Solution Building Blocks (SBBs) reside in the Solutions Continuum.

Each ABB in the Architecture Continuum can be realized by one or more SBBs in the Solutions Continuum.

docs.title: During Architecture Development
docs.text:
Architects move left to right on the continuum:

  1. Start with Foundation — Leverage generic models (e.g., TOGAF TRM)
  2. Adopt Common Systems — Incorporate standard patterns (e.g., integration patterns)
  3. Apply Industry — Use industry reference architectures (e.g., banking models)
  4. Customize to Organization — Tailor to specific business context

This accelerates architecture development by reusing existing assets.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text: Benefit Description Reuse Avoid reinventing the wheel Accelerate Leverage proven patterns Consistency Build on standards Interoperability Align with industry norms Context Understand positioning of work

docs.title: Architecture Repository
docs.text: The Architecture Repository is the physical store of architectural assets and artifacts.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The Architecture Repository provides: - Centralized storage for all architecture work products - Version control for architecture artifacts - Reusability through cataloging and classification - Governance tracking and compliance documentation - Collaboration enabling team access to shared assets

docs.title: Architecture Repository Structure
docs.text: The Architecture Repository has six main components:

docs.title: 1. Architecture Metamodel
docs.text: Content Purpose Metamodel definition Structure of architecture information Entity definitions Core architectural concepts (actor, process, data, app, tech) Relationships How entities relate Extensions Organization-specific metamodel enhancements

docs.title: 2. Architecture Landscape
docs.text:
The current and planned architectures organized by abstraction level:

Level Description Horizon Strategic Architecture Long-term, directional 3-5+ years Segment Architecture Specific business units or capabilities 1-3 years Capability Architecture Detailed architecture for specific capabilities 6-12 months

Each level contains: - Baseline architecture (current state) - Target architecture (desired future state) - Transition architectures (intermediate states)

docs.title: 3. Standards Information Base (SIB)
docs.text:
Content Purpose Technology standards Approved technologies, versions Industry standards Regulatory and compliance standards Principles Architecture principles Policies IT and architecture policies

The SIB provides the "rules" that architectures must comply with.

docs.title: 4. Reference Library
docs.text:
Content Purpose Reference architectures Industry and foundation architectures Patterns and templates Reusable architectural patterns Guidelines Best practices and how-to guides Architecture frameworks Methodologies (including tailored TOGAF)

The Reference Library provides reusable assets to accelerate architecture development.

docs.title: 5. Governance Log
docs.text:
Content Purpose Architecture decisions Rationale for key decisions Compliance assessments Results of governance reviews Dispensations Approved exceptions to standards Architecture contracts Agreements between architects and implementers Change requests Requests for architecture changes

The Governance Log provides accountability and traceability for architecture decisions.

docs.title: 6. Solutions Landscape
docs.text:
Content Purpose Implemented solutions Deployed systems and technologies Application portfolio Inventory of applications Technology portfolio Inventory of infrastructure Project portfolio Current and planned implementation projects

The Solutions Landscape shows what's actually deployed and running.

docs.title: Population and Maintenance
docs.text: Activity Frequency Purpose Add new architectures Per ADM cycle Capture architecture work products Update existing architectures Continuous Reflect changes and evolution Archive obsolete assets Periodic (e.g., annual) Manage repository size Review and purge Annual Remove outdated or irrelevant content Classify assets Ongoing Maintain organization and discoverability Ensure access control Ongoing Manage who can view/edit

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text:
Architecture assets should be version-controlled:

Version Type When to Use Major Significant architecture changes (1.0 → 2.0) Minor Incremental enhancements (1.1 → 1.2) Patch Corrections and clarifications (1.1.0 → 1.1.1)

docs.title: Integration with ADM
docs.text:
Phase Repository Interaction Preliminary Establish repository structure and governance Phase A Retrieve reference architectures, store Architecture Vision Phases B, C, D Retrieve patterns, store architecture definitions Phase E Retrieve solutions, store transition architectures Phase F Store implementation plans and roadmaps Phase G Store compliance assessments and contracts Phase H Update architectures based on changes, archive obsolete assets

The Repository is used throughout the ADM — it's the central knowledge base for enterprise architecture.

docs.title: Benefits of Architecture Repository
docs.text: Benefit Description Single source of truth Centralized, authoritative architecture information Reuse Discover and leverage existing assets Consistency Ensure alignment across projects Governance Track decisions and compliance Collaboration Enable team access and sharing Knowledge preservation Retain institutional knowledge Efficiency Accelerate architecture development

docs.title: Common Repository Challenges
docs.text: Challenge Mitigation Out-of-date content Regular reviews and updates Poor organization Clear classification and tagging Low adoption Demonstrate value, make easy to use Access issues Clear permissions, good search Tool complexity Training, simple interface

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Enterprise Continuum classifies assets from generic to specific
  • Two continua: Architecture Continuum (ABBs) and Solutions Continuum (SBBs)
  • Four levels in each: Foundation → Common Systems → Industry → Organization-Specific
  • Foundation = most generic; Organization-Specific = most tailored
  • Architecture Repository is the physical store of architecture assets
  • Six components: Metamodel, Landscape, Standards (SIB), Reference Library, Governance Log, Solutions Landscape
  • Architecture Landscape has three levels: Strategic, Segment, Capability
  • Standards Information Base (SIB) contains standards, principles, policies
  • Governance Log tracks decisions, compliance, contracts
  • Solutions Landscape shows deployed systems and projects
  • Enterprise Continuum provides classification; Repository provides storage
  • Continuum helps architects reuse and accelerate architecture development
  • Repository is used throughout ADM — central knowledge base

docs.title: Content Framework
docs.text: The TOGAF Content Framework provides a structural model for architecture content, defining the types of artifacts, deliverables, and building blocks produced during architecture development.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The Content Framework ensures: - Consistency in architecture outputs across projects - Completeness of architecture work products - Clear terminology for architecture artifacts - Structured approach to creating architecture content - Reusability of architecture components

docs.title: Content Metamodel
docs.text: The Content Metamodel defines the core entities and their relationships in enterprise architecture.

docs.title: Core Entities
docs.text: Entity Description Actor Person, organization, or system performing a role Role Responsibilities assumed by an actor Business Service Service supporting business capabilities Function Unit of business capability Process Sequence of activities delivering value Event Organizational state change triggering action Product Output from processes Data Entity Business information object Application Component Modular, deployable unit of software Technology Component Infrastructure element

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text: The metamodel can be extended to include: - Organization-specific entities - Industry-specific concepts - Detailed specializations

docs.title: Content Categories
docs.text: TOGAF organizes architecture content into three primary categories:

docs.title: 1. Deliverables
docs.text:
Deliverables are work products formally reviewed, agreed, and signed off by stakeholders.

Deliverable Purpose Key Phases Architecture Vision High-level aspirational description Phase A Architecture Definition Document Comprehensive architecture description Phases B, C, D Architecture Requirements Specification Quantified requirements Phases B, C, D Architecture Roadmap Timeline for implementation Phases E, F Implementation and Migration Plan Detailed implementation plan Phases E, F Architecture Contract Agreement for governance Phases F, G Compliance Assessment Conformance evaluation Phase G Statement of Architecture Work Scope and approach Phase A

Characteristics of deliverables: - Contractual — Formally approved - Reviewed — Subject to stakeholder sign-off - Versioned — Tracked and baselined - Managed — Under configuration control

docs.title: 2. Artifacts
docs.text: Artifacts are specific work products describing an aspect of architecture.

docs.title: Artifact Types
docs.text: Type Description Examples Catalogs Lists of things Organization Catalog, Application Portfolio, Technology Standards Matrices Relationships between things Stakeholder Map Matrix, Data Entity/Business Function Matrix Diagrams Visual representations Business Process Diagram, Application Communication Diagram

docs.title: Common Artifacts by Domain
docs.text:
Business Architecture: - Organization/Actor Catalog - Business Service/Function Catalog - Process Flow Diagram - Business Interaction Matrix - Business Capability Map

Data Architecture: - Data Entity/Data Component Catalog - Conceptual/Logical/Physical Data Models - Data Entity/Business Function Matrix - Data Lifecycle Diagram - Data Security Diagram

Application Architecture: - Application Portfolio Catalog - Interface Catalog - Application Communication Diagram - Application/Function Matrix - Application Deployment Diagram

Technology Architecture: - Technology Standards Catalog - Technology Portfolio Catalog - Technology Infrastructure Diagram - Network Diagram - Platform Decomposition Diagram

docs.title: 3. Building Blocks
docs.text:
Building Blocks represent (potentially reusable) components of architecture.

Type Description Architecture Building Block (ABB) Functional specification (what) Solution Building Block (SBB) Implementation specification (how)

See Building Blocks for detailed information.

docs.title: 1. Architecture Vision
docs.text: Content Purpose Problem description What problem is being solved? Objectives What is the goal? Baseline summary Current state Target summary Desired future state Value proposition Business benefits Stakeholder map Who is involved and their concerns

docs.title: 2. Architecture Definition Document (ADD)
docs.text:
Comprehensive definition containing:

Section Content Scope Boundaries and constraints Goals and objectives What architecture aims to achieve Architecture Views Multiple perspectives for stakeholders Baseline Architecture Current state (for each domain: B, D, A, T) Target Architecture Future state (for each domain: B, D, A, T) Gap Analysis Differences between baseline and target Impact Assessment Effects of changes

docs.title: 3. Architecture Requirements Specification
docs.text: Section Content Success measures KPIs and metrics Architecture requirements Standards, principles, patterns to follow Business requirements What business needs Data requirements Data quality, governance, integration Application requirements Functionality and integration Technology requirements Infrastructure, platforms, non-functional Constraints Budget, time, resource, technical limitations Assumptions Dependencies and pre-conditions

docs.title: 4. Architecture Roadmap
docs.text: Content Purpose Work packages Grouped initiatives Transition architectures Intermediate states Timeline When initiatives occur Dependencies Sequencing constraints Milestones Key decision/delivery points

docs.title: 5. Implementation and Migration Plan
docs.text: Section Content Project portfolio List of implementation projects Resource plan Staffing and budget Schedule Detailed timeline with Gantt chart Risk register Risks and mitigation strategies Business case ROI and value justification Communications plan Stakeholder engagement approach

docs.title: Catalogs (Lists)
docs.text:
Catalogs provide inventories of architectural elements:

Catalog Purpose Organization Catalog Organizational units, locations, actors Role Catalog Roles and responsibilities Business Service Catalog Services provided to customers Application Portfolio Catalog All applications in enterprise Technology Portfolio Catalog Technology products in use Standards Catalog Approved standards and versions

docs.title: Matrices (Relationships)
docs.text:
Matrices show relationships between architectural elements:

Matrix Relates Purpose Stakeholder Map Matrix Stakeholders ↔ Concerns Ensure concerns are addressed Actor/Role Matrix Actors ↔ Roles Show who performs what Business Service/Function Matrix Services ↔ Functions Map services to functions Data Entity/Function Matrix Data ↔ Functions Show which functions use which data Application/Function Matrix Applications ↔ Functions Map applications to business functions Application Communication Matrix Applications ↔ Applications Show integration points

docs.title: Diagrams (Visuals)
docs.text:
Diagrams provide visual representations:

Diagram Type Purpose Example Process Flow Show business process steps Order-to-cash process Organizational Depict structure and reporting Organization chart Data Flow Show data movement Data flows between systems Application Communication Show application integration Integration architecture Network Show network topology Network diagram Deployment Show where things run Application deployment view

docs.title: Tailoring the Content Framework
docs.text: Organizations should adapt the Content Framework:

docs.title: What to Tailor
docs.text: Element Adaptation Deliverables Select relevant deliverables for context Artifacts Choose artifacts addressing stakeholder concerns Level of detail Adjust depth based on scope and audience Terminology Use organizational language Templates Create standardized templates Metamodel Extend with organization-specific concepts

docs.title: Tailoring Principles
docs.text:
• Fit for purpose — Create only what adds value
  • Stakeholder-driven — Address stakeholder concerns
  • Proportionate — Detail appropriate to scope
  • Reusable — Leverage existing content
  • Consistent — Follow organizational standards

docs.title: Architecture Repository Integration
docs.text:
Content Framework outputs are stored in the Architecture Repository:

Repository Component Content Stored Architecture Metamodel Content metamodel and extensions Architecture Landscape Baseline and target architectures Standards Information Base Standards catalogs and specifications Reference Library Templates, patterns, guidelines Governance Log Decisions, compliance assessments, contracts

docs.title: Content Framework and ADM
docs.text:
How Content Framework applies across ADM:

Phase Key Deliverables Key Artifacts Preliminary Tailored Architecture Framework Principles Catalog, Stakeholder Map Phase A Architecture Vision, Statement of Architecture Work Stakeholder Map, Business Capability Map Phase B Architecture Definition Document (Business) Process Flow, Organization Diagram, Capability Map Phase C Architecture Definition Document (Data + Application) Data Models, Application Portfolio, Interface Catalog Phase D Architecture Definition Document (Technology) Network Diagram, Platform Decomposition Phase E Architecture Roadmap (draft) Work Package Catalog, Transition Architectures Phase F Implementation and Migration Plan Project Portfolio, Gantt Chart, Business Case Phase G Compliance Assessments, Architecture Contracts Compliance Reports Phase H Architecture Updates Change Requests, Lessons Learned

docs.title: Exam Tips
docs.text:
• Content Framework defines structure for architecture artifacts
  • Three main categories: Deliverables, Artifacts, Building Blocks
  • Deliverables are formally reviewed and signed off
  • Artifacts are specific work products (Catalogs, Matrices, Diagrams)
  • Catalogs = lists, Matrices = relationships, Diagrams = visuals
  • Key deliverables: Architecture Vision, Architecture Definition Document, Requirements Specification, Roadmap, Implementation Plan, Architecture Contract
  • Architecture Definition Document contains baseline + target for all domains (BDAT)
  • Content Metamodel defines core entities (Actor, Role, Function, Process, Data Entity, Application, Technology)
  • Content Framework can be tailored to organizational needs
  • Deliverables are stored in Architecture Repository

docs.title: Reference Models (TRM & III-RM)
docs.text: TOGAF provides two reference models as Foundation Architectures: the Technical Reference Model (TRM) and the Integrated Information Infrastructure Reference Model (III-RM).

docs.title: Purpose of Reference Models
docs.text: Reference models provide: - Common vocabulary for platform services and components - Taxonomy for classifying technology - Starting point for architecture development - Completeness check ensuring all necessary services are considered - Vendor-neutral descriptions of capabilities

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The TRM is a Foundation Architecture providing a taxonomy of generic platform services that support applications.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The TRM: - Classifies technology components into categories - Ensures completeness of technology architecture - Provides standard terminology - Acts as starting point for creating organization-specific TRM

docs.title: TRM Structure
docs.text:
The TRM organizes platform services into layers (from bottom to top):

┌─────────────────────────────────────────┐
│        Application Software             │  ← Applications
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│      Application Platform Services      │  ← Layer 7
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│      Software Engineering Services      │  ← Layer 6
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   Communication & Network Services      │  ← Layer 5
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│    Data Management Services             │  ← Layer 4
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   Transaction Processing Services       │  ← Layer 3
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   System & Network Management Services  │  ← Layer 2
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│      Security Services                  │  ← Layer 1
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│      Operating System Services          │  ← Base
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│         Network Infrastructure          │  ← Foundation
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│        Hardware (Compute, Storage)      │  ← Physical
└─────────────────────────────────────────┘
